attributes.title: Mindless Math
attributes.description: Looking at people's self-reports of mechanism and manipulating the order of presentation of content.

q1.value: Asher Lawson, Richard P. Larrick, Jack B. Soll

q2.value:
H1: We predict that participants will respond correctly at a higher rate in the 'easier' numeric demands condition relative to the 'harder' numeric demands condition.

H2: We predict that participants will report they used the mechanism 'I did not add any numbers together.' at a higher rate in the 'easier' numeric demands condition relative to the 'harder' numeric demands condition.

H3: We predict that participants will report they used the mechanism 'I added numbers together, and I used the sum in my final answer.' at a lower rate in the 'easier' numeric demands condition relative to the 'harder' numeric demands condition.

H4: We predict that there will not be significant differences in participants' reports of the number of times they read the first sentence of the problem across the 'easier' numeric demands condition and the 'harder' numeric demands condition.

H5: We predict that there will not be significant differences in the rate at which participants' report that they believed the experimenter was tricking them across the 'easier' numeric demands condition and the 'harder' numeric demands condition.

H6: We predict that there will not be significant differences in participants' reports of the difficulty of the problem relative to their expectations across the 'easier' numeric demands condition and the 'harder' numeric demands condition.

H7: We predict a significant positive effect of our order manipulation, such that people respond correctly at a higher rate when the 'Imagine Joey is going to the store to buy a pack of chips' sentence is placed later in the problem.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a 2x2 between-subjects design.

q7.value: Participants are randomized to a study condition. This occurs after an attention check and comprehension check, both of which eject participants if failed.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: This will be posted on mTurk. Participants will be paid $0.31. We will required; HITs Approved: 0-50000, Approval Rate: 97+, Only: United States, and participants who have completed any other associated study will be precluded from participating.

q11.value: We will target a sample of N = 600. Because the participants are able to select the numbers that feature in their problem, it is important to have large cell sizes (N = 300) to get responses from a representative sample of problems.

question.value:
We will manipulate the numeric demands of the study item participants face. Participants will select three numbers that will form the basis of the problem they answer. In the easier numeric demands condition, these are selected from the list (0.50, 1.00... 5.00). In the harder numeric demands condition, these are selected from a list containing more complex numbers (e.g. 0.30, 0.75).

We will also manipulate the order of problem elements - the information that is key to representation will either be placed before or after the numeric content.

We measure success as a binary outcome variable. Due to the nature of the stem of the problem, if a participant returns the middle number they selected, this is coded as correct. This varies by participant, as they are able to select which numbers are in the problem.

Participants are asked to choose the process that most closely matches how they completed the problem from the list below. These are then coded into dummy indicators (0 if not selected, 1 if selected).
I did not add any numbers together.
I added numbers together, but did not use the sum in my final answer.
I added numbers together, and I used the sum in my final answer.

Times_read = participants self report how many times they read the first sentence of the question

If participants responded that they read the stem more than once, they are asked to indicate any reasons that apply for why they reread it from the below list. They could select multiple options. These were then coded into dummy variables (0 if not selected, 1 if selected)
I could not remember the question.
The problem looked easier than I expected.
I thought the experimenter might be tricking me.

Participants were then asked to report on a scale coded -3 to 3 how easy / hard the problem was relative to their expectation.

To test the differences in our binary outcome variables, we use logistic regression with numeric demands as the sole independent variable. To test the differences between times_read and difficulty, we use t-tests.

attributes.title: Vicarious intergroup contact effects
attributes.description: The study constitutes a conceptual replication of Mazziotta et al. (2011, GPIR, doi: .1177/1368430210390533)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The Influence of vicarious Intergroup contact on willingness for direct intergroup contact – a conceptual replication study by Mazziotta et al. (2011)

other.value: The study constitutes a conceptual replication of Mazziotta et al. (2011, GPIR, doi: .1177/1368430210390533)

outliers.value: Participants with a migrant background will be removed from the data set.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables: Willingness for contact, intergroup affect
Measurement: Participants are instructed to imagine working in a market research institute and being faced with the task of conducting unstructured interviews with members of two ethnic groups. Participants are then told that they will be asked to describe their feelings and behavioral intentions towards these groups.

conditions.value: There are two experimental conditions: In the experimental condition participants will be confronted with images displaying intercultural contact between an ingroup as well as an outgroup member. In the control condition participants will be confronted with images displaying contact between ingroup members.

hypothesis.value:
Hypotheses 1
A: Participants that observe vicarious contact, express more willingness for direct contact than participants that do not observe vicarious contact. 

B: Participants that observe vicarious contact express more positive intergroup affect than participants that do not observe vicarious contact. 

C: Participants that observe vicarious contact express higher self-efficacy expectation than participants that do not observe vicarious contact.

D: Participants that observe vicarious contact express lower intergroup uncertainty than participants that do not observe vicarious contact.

Hypotheses 2 
A: The relationship between vicarious contact and willingness for contact is mediated by increased self-efficacy expectation

B: The relationship between vicarious contact and willingness for contact is mediated by decreased intergroup uncertainty.

attributes.title: Moral Decision-Making in the Time of COVID-19
attributes.description: An investigation of moral decision-making  in the time of COVID-19

q2.value:
Hypothesis I:  People may be more likely to be utilitarian during the COVID-19 pandemic than they were prior to the pandemic. This may result from a shift in social context which is focused on saving lives and acting for the greater good. However, people may also be less utilitarian during the pandemic as a result of mortality salience. 

Hypothesis II: People's Moralisation of Everyday Life during COVID-19 Scale (MELS-CV19) scores will predict their current behaviours (e.g., social distancing, hand washing, volunteering). In terms of the direction of this relationship, the moralisation of behaviours such as social distancing may shape social norms in favour of adhering to these behaviours. However, moralisation may also result in individuals feeling judged and subsequently decreasing adherence to these behaviours. 

Hypothesis III: People’s moral principles (e.g., their endorsement of utilitarian principles) prior to and during the COVID-19 pandemic may predict certain behaviours that they are currently engaging in (i.e., social distancing, resisting the temptation to hoard, and volunteering).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study is a within-subjects repeated measures single group design with 1 experimental factor (the COVID-19 pandemic).

To evaluate the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic within participants, we will recruit participants who took part in a previous study investigating the consistency of moral decision-making across paired moral dilemmas (with matched moral conditions). Participants previously responded to 34 moral dilemmas (17 dilemma pairs) at one time point, in addition to the Oxford Utilitarianism Scale. 7 dilemma pairs with consistency of at least 75% were identified in this and an additional previous study (osf.io/kq325) and will be used to measure utilitarian responding in the current (follow-up) study.

In this study, participants will be asked to complete a short questionnaire (the Oxford Utilitarianism Scale – 9 items: http://www.jimaceverett.com/resources/oxford-utilitarianism-scale/), in addition to the following three measures, which will be counterbalanced between participants (details of measures provided in Appendix 1):
1)	Participants will be asked questions about their current behaviours relating to the COVID-19 pandemic
2)	Participants will be presented with a set of 14 moral dilemmas (7 dilemma pairs) that we have previously found to produce “highly consistent responses over time” and will be asked to respond to these. Participants will have seen all of these dilemmas before (during the original moral decision-making study)
3)	Participants will be asked to respond to the Adapted MELS-CV19 (Moralization of Everyday Life during COVID-19 Scale) using a Likert-type scale.

Participants will also be asked to answer two questions related to whether they or someone in their immediate social environment has been infected with COVID-19. These questions are placed at the end of the study so they do not influence responses to the other questions. 

Following completion of the study session, participants will be provided with a debrief which includes the researcher contact details should they have any additional questions. 

No direct control group (i.e. follow-up in the absence of a pandemic) is included in the study. However, data from a previous study where participants completed follow-up under "normal" conditions (https://osf.io/kq325) after 2-4 weeks will be analysed in the same way to ensure that effects observed during the COVID-19 pandemic are not simply due to timing.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: Only data from timepoint 1 (baseline/prior to COVID-19) have been collected prior to this pre-registration. We have only used these data to establish which moral dilemma pairs produce the most consistent moral decisions within participants. No data from during the COVID-19 pandemic have been collected at this stage, we are merely using the data from timepoint 1 as a baseline.

question.value:
Participants will be invited to participate through Prolific, an online participant database. Prolific allows the researcher to set “prerequisite” criteria for participants and we will use this feature to recruit participants who have already taken part in our original study. This is a paid participation study and participants will be paid £7.50 per hour for their time.

Participants must have taken part in the previous online study [University of Bradford: E747; University of Reading: 2019-013] and be willing to provide informed consent. Participants are all 18 years of age or over. There are no gender, race, or religious constraints on study participation and all participants have good (or corrected) vision and basic literacy skills and proficiency in English (as these were the eligibility criteria for the original study).

There are no exclusion criteria for this study.

We will recruit until as many of the original participant pool as possible have participated, though we expect that this will not continue past the end of May 2020.

q11.value: Given that this study has been designed to collect data from previous participants, our sample size is limited to the number originally recruited (N = 107).

q12.value:
This number was previously chosen to provide sufficient power to identify dilemmas with strong intra-subject consistency (consistency >= 75%). 
Recruiting the same participants will allow us to investigate how moral principles at baseline relate to behaviours, moral decision-making and moralisation during a socially and ethically relevant crisis.

question.value: There are no manipulated variables in this study.

Details of the experimental measures are provided in Appendix 1.
-The outcome variable for each moral dilemma question will be a binary answer ('yes' or 'no') regarding whether the participant would perform the utilitarian action (harming one person to save many) described in that dilemma. 
-Utilitarian tendency will be assessed using the Oxford Utilitarianism Scale.
-Moralisation of daily behaviours will be assessed using the Moralization of Everyday Life during COVID-19 Scale. Participants will be asked to respond using a Likert-type scale (0 - not wrong at all; a perfectly OK action to 6 - very wrong; an extremely immoral action).
-Participants' current behaviours will be assessed using a current behaviours questionnaire and responses will be given on a Likert-type scale (0 -I never do this, 1 - I rarely do this, 3 - I sometimes do this, 4 - I often do this, 5 - I always do this). A “Not Applicable” response option is provided for items 3, 5, 6, and 9.

The proportion of utilitarian responses will be analysed across all dilemmas for each participant (mean response (1 or 0) across all dilemmas). 

Oxford Utilitarianism Scale scores will include total (9-item) scores as well as Impartial beneficence (5-item) and Instrumental Harm (4-item) sub scores.

We will perform a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of the moralisation measures to determine which items are most appropriately grouped with one another. Composite scores of each component will then be used for further analysis.

We will perform a PCA of the current behaviour measures to determine which items are most appropriately grouped with one another. Composite scores of each component will then be used for further analysis. If a participant answers "not applicable" for an item, this item will not count toward the composite score.

To test Hypothesis I, we will use a paired t-test to compare the utilitarian proportion (average response rate across all dilemmas) for each participant before and during the COVID-19 pandemic. We will conduct the same analysis for the Oxford Utilitarian Scale total and sub scale scores before and during the pandemic.

To test Hypothesis II, we will first conduct a principal components analysis (PCA) for both the MELS-CV19 and current behaviour questionnaires. PCA creates one or more index variables from a larger set of measured variables. For this analysis, we will retain all principal components with eigenvalues >1. We will then perform a regression of composite scores for each component (mean score of items within a component) of the MELS-CV19 against composite scores for each of the components obtained for current behaviour. Participants' responses to the symptom history questions (included in Appendix 1) will be included as covariates only if these items are statistically significantly associated with responses on the MELS-CV19 or current behaviours questionnaire.

To test Hypothesis III, we will perform a regression analysis of Oxford Utilitarianism Scale score (total and sub-scale scores) at baseline against each factor of the current behaviours questionnaire. If Oxford Utilitarianism Scores at time 2 (during the COVID-19 pandemic) are statistically significantly different from those obtained at time 1 (baseline), this analysis will also be conducted using Oxford Utilitarianism Scale scores obtained during the COVID-19 pandemic. We will also look at the relationship between utilitarian proportion in sacrificial moral dilemmas and their current behaviours (the same decisions will be made regarding T1 and T2 data as above).

q18.value: For each moral dilemma, the response is binary (yes or no). These responses will be re-coded numerically to 1 (yes) and 0 (no).

q19.value:
We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if differences obtained between time points in the paired t-test are statistically significant (Hypothesis I). 
A threshold of p<.05 will also be used to determine statistical significance of regression analyses (Hypotheses II & III).

q20.value: Only incomplete data sets (including participants who completed the study at time 1 but did not take part in time 2) will be excluded.

q21.value: Any incomplete data sets will be excluded from the analysis.

This may result from a shift in social context which is focused on saving lives and acting for the greater good. However, people may also be less utilitarian during the pandemic as a result of mortality salience. 

Hypothesis II: People's Moralisation of Everyday Life during COVID-19 Scale (MELS-CV19) scores will predict their current behaviours (e.g., social distancing, hand washing, volunteering). In terms of the direction of this relationship, the moralisation of behaviours such as social distancing may shape social norms in favour of adhering to these behaviours. However, moralisation may also result in individuals feeling judged and subsequently decreasing adherence to these behaviours. 

Hypothesis III: People’s moral principles (e.g., their endorsement of utilitarian principles) prior to and during the COVID-19 pandemic may predict certain behaviours that they are currently engaging in (i.e., social distancing, resisting the temptation to hoard, and volunteering).

q2.value: If concentration is proportional to fiber diameter, then higher concentration fibers will produce larger diameter fibers.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Different concentrations and different draw rates were used to produce multiple different fiber diameters and bundles. Changing the draw rate allowed the user to make several different collagen fiber bundles that could be used for different experiments.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Data was collected by measuring the diameter of fibers on a scanning electron microscope. Several bundles were collected and the diameter of selected fibers were measured to take an average diameter based on concentration and draw rate.

q11.value: Our sample size was 50 different bundles per each concentration and draw rate. We made several more for other studies.

question.value:
Diameter of fiber
Concentration of collagen solution
Rate of drawing
Rate of extrusion
We ran multiple regressions.

attributes.title: Sport and pelvic floor dysfunction in male and female athletes: A scoping review protocol
attributes.description:
BACKGROUND. Pelvic floor dysfunction is a term used to describe a variety of symptoms, signs and conditions involving different impairments on the pelvic floor muscles. 
The existing literature suggests that sport has many health benefits. However, some of these lead to a higher risk of developing pelvic floor dysfunction. No study and review have been conducted to map the entire phenomena in the sport population.
The objective of this scoping review is to summarize the literature to identify the available evidence of pelvic floor dysfunction among male and female athletes. 
INCLUSION CRITERIA. Any female and male athletes of any age with pelvic floor dysfunction. Any sports, performance level and dysfunctions will be included. Any context will be considered for inclusion. 
METHODS. This scoping review will be performed in accordance with the Joanna Briggs Institute methodology. MEDLINE, Cochrane Central, Scopus, CINHAL, Embase and PEDro database will be searched from inception to March 2020. Additional records will be identified through searching in grey literature and the reference lists of all relevant studies. No study design, publication type, data and language restrictions will be applied. 
Two reviewers will independently screen all abstracts and full-text studies for inclusion. A data collection form will be developed by the research team to extract the characteristics of the studies included. A tabular and accompanying narrative summary of the information will be provided.
CONCLUSIONS. This will be the first scoping review to provide a comprehensive overview of the topic. The results will add meaningful information for clinicians especially during the patient’s assessment. Furthermore, any knowledge gaps of the topic will be identified. The results of this research will be published in a peer-reviewed journal and will be presented at relevant (inter)national scientific events.

attributes.title: Clarithromycin Project  (Macrolide) as a Therapeutic or Prophylatic as a Single Agent for Covid19.
attributes.description: We have presented this Project to our Health Minister here in Argentina by middle of March without having any answer from them yet. We made it public by internet. The main idea is to use a Macrolide specially Clarithromycin as a Single Agent ( without any other drug ) for Therapy or Prophylaxis of Covid19 virus.
tags: MACROLIDE CLARITHROMYCIN AS SINGLE AGENT FOR COVID19

q2.value:
Everyone believes;  I think, that Azithromycin acts as an antibacterial agent for associated pneumonia.
The results of the Marcella people I believe, can be explained only in
three simple ways:

1) Azythromicin acts synergistically with OH-Chloroquine;
2) Azythromicin has an anti-viral effect independent of that of OH-Chloroquine.
3)   Both possibilities act in unison.

No one has come out to open the scene on this yet.

I attend many sick people in my office; many (until this came).
In winters for many years I have been using Clarithromycin (which I
have seen is more effective than Azithromycin) 
when almost 90 percent of the consultations are feverish respiratory
symptoms; many of them only medicated with paracetamol for being
considered viral by the Medical On Duty Rooms  and that in view of the aggravation or persistence of the picture consult me. The fever and the clinical picture improve miraculously 24 hours after giving
Clarithromycin strikingly. I have seen this for years in hundreds or
thousands of patients. I always thought that the causative agents were mycoplasmas but slowly I began to convince myself that the action could also be antiviral.

Before this epidemic then and after the association they made with
Hidoxychloroquine and Azithromycin, I quickly made the deduction : 

“ more inclined to think from my experience that the action in this situation would be for macrolides eminently antiviral ”. Azihromycin pharmacologically, could theoretically have better lung penetration. But according to my experience and that of the literature;
As an antiviral Clarithromycine would be much better. 

That is why it would be essential to use Clarithromycin.

This (Clarithromycin as treatment or Prophylaxis As Single Agent)
according to my perception could change the history of the pandemic
and medicine. It would reduce the cost of the treatment and the
potential adverse effects when associating other drugs like
hydroxychloroquine.

It would be immediately available globally. It would immediately
protect health workers. It would avoid the mortality associated with
the disease. It would accelerate the inactivation of the viral load. I
would avoid the economic debacle of the world. And if in an effort by
all the governments of our planet it were given for a few days at the
same time to all the inhabitants of the earth it would allow to
eradicate the virus in 5 or 8 days

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
PURPOSE OF THE PROTOCOL:
To Guarantee the detection and early diagnosis of a possible new case coronavirus (COVID-19)patient and even healthy carriers, in order to allow its inclusion in a research protocol with the exclusive use of Clarithromycin 500 long acting formulation that allows its administration once a day for 8 days and check if this treatment per se is able to reduce or make disappear the viral load of that new case or healthy carrier.


Triage: 
Given the selection of the probable case and / or possible healthy carrier, and not having criteria of severity, after obtaining chest X-ray that does not indicate serious pulmonary compromise or dyspnea or other serious organic alteration, the oropharynx sample will be obtained and / or or nasopharynx and will be sent for PCR (to the Reference center) for Covid-19.

PRIMARY PROPHYLAXIS:

The main objective of epidemiological surveillance in the current situation is early detection of healthy cases or carriers, allowing the adequate care of patients and the implementation of research, prevention and control measures aimed at reducing the risk of spread of infection in the population.

Current evidence suggests that person-to-person spread is occurring, even among healthcare workers caring for patients suffering from COVID-19, which would be consistent with what is known about other similar pathogens.  
So far, no drugs or combinations have been recommended, nor are vaccines approved for the use of antiviral prophylaxis before or after exposure to COVID-19 available, since there is no evidence to support their use.
If clarithromycin reduced itself without the addition of any drugs plus the viral load of infected patients or carriers or positive contacts for the virus, the potential administration of only 8 days of global or global prophylaxis of Clarithromycin 500 UD could definitively end and in a few days with the pandemic.
It would also even be interesting to see its prophylactic effect on members of the health team directly involved in the care of patients of these characteristics.
Hence the urgent need for this trial.
TWO POSSIBLE VERY SIMPLE PROTOCOLS THAT SHOULD BE STARTED IMMEDIATELY AND SIMULTANEOUSLY:


1. TO DEMONSTRATE THE ANTIVIRAL AND THERAPEUTIC EFFECTIVENESS OF 500 MG OF ORAL CLARITHROMYCIN PROLONGED RELEASE FORMULATION AS A SOLE AGENT. 

POSSIBILITY TO END THE PANDEMIC WITH ONLY ONE CYCLE OF THIS SCHEME IF OFFERED TO THE WHOLE WORLD POPULATION IN SIMULTANEOUS. 

CASE RECRUITMENT PARAMETERS FOR OPTION 1 

PATIENTS WITH INITIAL SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS (AT THE BEGINNING OF SYMPTOMS IN CLINICALLY UNCOMPLICATED SICKNESS NOT COMMITTED TO GRAVITY CLINICALLY) 
RX THORAX APPARENTLY WITHOUT OR VERY LITTLE PULMONARY COMMITMENT 
CT EVENTUALLY WITH MINIMUM SIGNS 
GENERAL ANALYSIS WITHOUT SERIOUS FAILURES 
GENERAL ANALYSIS: 
HEMOGRAM ERS UREA GLYCEMIA CREATININ HEPATOGRAM LDH SPECIFIC ANALYSIS 
RX 
CT ( IT WOULD BE VERY USEFUL BUT I DON'T KNOW IF THE CENTERS WANT TO SPEND THAT MONEY IF THE RX LOOKS GOOD OR EVEN IF THE LUNG IS VERY COMMITTED IN RX THE URGENCY WILL NOT ALLOW TO DO MANY STUDIES BUT IF YOU CAN IT IS ADDED ) 
QUICK TEST FOR COVID 19 PCR FOR COVID 19 EVENTUALLY 
PHARINGED ISOPATE FOR INFLUENZA VIRUSES AND OTHER NON-COVID RESPIRATORIES (THIS IS NOT ESSENTIAL)


IF THERE IS NO CONTRAINDICATION 

BEGINS WITH CLARITHROMYCIN 500 LONG ACTING FORMULATION ONE PER DAY ORAL

 IF THE QUICK TEST GIVES NEGATIVE CONTINUES CLARITHROMYCIN

IF IGM POSITIVE IT CONTINUES ON RECEIVING THE DRUG
IF THE PCR POSITIVE  AND HAVE NOT WORSEN AT 48-72 HOURS OR BETTER CONTINUE DRUG FOR 8 DAYS.

 IF PCR POSITIVE AND HAS GOT WORST, ADD HYDROXYCHLOROKINE AND ENTER IF IT IS POSSIBLE TO THE HOSPTITAL.

IF PCR POSITIVE POSITIVE AND HAS NOT WORSEN ON THE 3RD DAY, THE RX IS REPEATED AND IT IS REPEATED PCR FOR COVID 19 AND CONTINUES THE 8 DAYS IN THE SAME WAY OF NEGATIVE OR POSITIVE.

 IF THE PATIENT DOES NOT WORSEN ON THE 8TH DAY, CLARITHROMYCIN IS STOP AND IN DAY 9 WILL DO RX AND PCR AGAIN. 

THE PATIENT IS FOLLOWED FOR ANOTHER WEEK AND IF IT DOES NOT WORSEN REPEAT THE QUICK TEST IF POSSIBLE. 
IF THE PATIENT GETS WORST AT ANY TIME, HE GOES INTO THE HOSPITAL IF POSSIBLE AND RECEIVES HIDOXICLOROQUIN WITH THE CLARITHROMYCIN.


OPTION 2 

( IT CAN / SHOULD BE DONE IN SIMULTANEOUS WITH OPTION 1) 

HEALTH PERSONNEL STRONGLY EXPOSED AND WITH A SIMILAR DEGREE OF EXPOSURE TO COVID 19. 

(IN FULL EPIDEMIC THEY SHOULD BE THE MOST EXPOSED IN ADMISSION ROOMS) WHILE THE STUDY LASTS. 

TWO GROUPS OF 20 DOCTORS / NURSES ARE SELECTED EACH OF BOTH GROUPS DO: 
COVID 19 QUICK TEST (IgM-IgG) AND COVID 19 PCR IF IT IS POSSIBLE.

OR  PCR ALONE. 

CLINICALLY THEY SIGN THAT THEY FEEL HEALTHY 
THEY DON'T TAKE ANY OTHER MEDICATION DURING THE COURSE OF THE STUDY 
THEY DO RX IF NOT BEING PREGNANT IF A WOMAN. 
THEY ALL SHOULD NOT HAVE SIGNS OF PULMONARY INVOLVEMENT. 

GROUP 1

IF NO CONTRAINDICATION ON DAY 1 OF RECRUITMENT BEGINS: CLARITHROMYCIN 500 LONG ACTING FORMULATION 1 X DAY FOR 15 DAYS 

GROUP 2 NOTHING

POSITIVES AT THE BEGINNING OF EITHER OF THE TWO GROUPS BEGIN
CLARITHROMICINA 500 LONG ACTING FORMULATION ONCE A DAY AND ARE FOLLOWED ACCORDING TO OPTION 1 OF THESE PROTOCOLS IN DOMESTIC INSULATION WHILE THEY DO NOT WORSE.

ALL PEOPLE IS FOLLOWED FOR 15 DAYS 

THOSE WHO WORSE DESPITE BEING WITH CLARITHROMYCIN IN GROUP 1 ARE CARRIED OUT AND HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE IS STARTED IN THE HOSPITAL IF POSSIBLE.

THEY LEAVE THE GROUP IN THESE CASES AND ARE NOT REPLACED.

AT DAY 8 PCR IS REPEATED ON EVERYONE AND RX THORAX ALSO

ON THE 15TH DAY PCR AND RX THORAX ARE REPEATED

IF AVAILABLE RAPID TESTS ( IgM-IgG are also done at the same times ).

THE RESULTS ARE STATISTICALLY ANALYZED AND COMMUNICATED / PUBLISHED

IF ENCOURAGING THESE RESULTS:
 
IT WILL BE PROPOSE TO THE GOVERNMENTS OF THE WORLD AND QUICKLY:

TO MANAGE ALL THE WORLD POPULATION THAT DOES NOT HAVE A CONTRAINDICATION AND SIMULTANEOUSLY AROUND THE WORLD ONE CYCLE OF CLARITHROMYCIN 500 LONG ACTING FORMULATION 1 X DAY FOR 8 DAYS ORAL. 

AND THE VIRUS THEN DISAPPEARS FROM THE FACE OF THE EARTH.

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value:
Eligibility Criteria
Go to   
Choosing to participate in a study is an important personal decision. Talk with your doctor and family members or friends about deciding to join a study. To learn more about this study, you or your doctor may contact the study research staff using the contacts provided below. For general information, Learn About Clinical Studies.


Ages Eligible for Study:   	18 Years and older   (Adult, Older Adult)
Sexes Eligible for Study:   	All
Accepts Healthy Volunteers:   	No

Criteria
Inclusion Criteria:
•	Adult (age ≥ 18 years)
•	Confirmed OR suspected COVID-19,
o	Confirmed: Positive assay for COVID-19 within the last 3 days ( PCR and/or Rapid IgM-IgG Test )
o	Suspected: Pending assay for COVID-19 ( PCR and/or Rapid IgM-IgG Test )
WITH high clinical suspicion.
•	Mild or Moderate Covid19. No need for hospitalization.

Exclusion Criteria:
•	Allergy to Clarithromycin or Macrolides
•	History of bone marrow transplant
•	Chronic hemodialysis or Glomerular Filtration Rate < 20ml/min
•	Pregnant or nursing
•	Severe liver disease

q11.value:
Study Type  :	Interventional  (Clinical Trial)
Estimated Enrollment  :	300 participants
Allocation:	Randomized
Intervention Model:	Parallel Assignment
Masking:	None (Open Label)
Primary Purpose:	Treatment
Official Title:	Clarithromycin as single agent for Patients With Suspected 
or Confirmed COVID-19.
Estimated Study Start Date  :	March 28 , 2020
Estimated Primary Completion Date  :	May 20, 2020
Estimated Study Completion Date  :	July 20, 2020

question.value: ONE ARM IS THERAPEUTIC AND THE OTHER PROPHYLACTIC

Outcome Measures
Go to   

Primary Outcome Measures  :
1.	COVID Ordinal Outcomes Scale at 14 days [ Time Frame: Assessed once on day 0, 3, 8 and 15 after enrollment (enrollment is day 0) ]
Per https://www.who.int/blueprint/priority-diseases/key-action/COVID-19_Treatment_Trial_Design_Master_Protocol_synopsis_Final_18022020.pdf, this scale reflects a range from uninfected to dead, where 0 is "no clinical or virological evidence of infection", 1 is "no limitation of activities", 2 is "limitation of activities", 3 is "hospitalized, no oxygen therapy", 4 is "oxygen by mask or nasal prongs", 5 is "non-invasive ventilation or high-flow oxygen", 6 is "intubation and mechanical ventilation", 7 is "ventilation + additional organ support - pressors, RRT (renal replacement therapy), ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation)", and 8 is "death".
 Primary Outcome Measures  :
1.	Hospitalization [ Time Frame: 14 days ]
All-cause hospitalization
1.	 Viral load [ Time Frame: 3 days ]
2.	Viral load by collected nasal swab and PCR [ Time Frame: 7 days ]

Secondary Outcome Measures  :
1.	Hospital-free days at 28 days (number of days patient not in hospital) [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 28 days after admission (day 28) ]
Calculated as a worst-rank ordinal (death is counted as -1 days).

2.	Ventilator-free days at 28 days (number of days patient not on a ventilator) [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 28 days after admission (day 28) ]
Calculated as a worst-rank ordinal (death is counted as -1 days).

3.	ICU-free days at 28 days (number of days patient not in an ICU) [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 28 days after admission (day 28) ]
Calculated as a worst-rank ordinal (death is counted as -1 days).

4.	Time to a 1-point decrease in the WHO ordinal recovery score [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 14 days after admission (day 14) ]
ANOVA

ALL PEOPLE IS FOLLOWED FOR 15 DAYS

THEY LEAVE THE GROUP IN THESE CASES AND ARE NOT REPLACED.

AT DAY 8 PCR IS REPEATED ON EVERYONE AND RX THORAX ALSO

ON THE 15TH DAY PCR AND RX THORAX ARE REPEATED

IF AVAILABLE RAPID TESTS ( IgM-IgG are also done at the same times ).

THE RESULTS ARE STATISTICALLY ANALYZED AND COMMUNICATED / PUBLISHED

IF ENCOURAGING THESE RESULTS:
 
IT WILL BE PROPOSE TO THE GOVERNMENTS OF THE WORLD AND QUICKLY:

TO MANAGE ALL THE WORLD POPULATION THAT DOES NOT HAVE A CONTRAINDICATION AND SIMULTANEOUSLY AROUND THE WORLD ONE CYCLE OF CLARITHROMYCIN 500 LONG ACTING FORMULATION 1 X DAY FOR 8 DAYS ORAL. 

AND THE VIRUS THEN DISAPPEARS FROM THE FACE OF THE EARTH.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Eligibility Criteria
Go to   
Choosing to participate in a study is an important personal decision. Talk with your doctor and family members or friends about deciding to join a study. To learn more about this study, you or your doctor may contact the study research staff using the contacts provided below. For general information, Learn About Clinical Studies.


Ages Eligible for Study:   	18 Years and older   (Adult, Older Adult)
Sexes Eligible for Study:   	All
Accepts Healthy Volunteers:   	No

Criteria
Inclusion Criteria:
•	Adult (age ≥ 18 years)
•	Confirmed OR suspected COVID-19,
o	Confirmed: Positive assay for COVID-19 within the last 3 days ( PCR and/or Rapid IgM-IgG Test )
o	Suspected: Pending assay for COVID-19 ( PCR and/or Rapid IgM-IgG Test )
WITH high clinical suspicion.
•	Mild or Moderate Covid19. No need for hospitalization.

Exclusion Criteria:
•	Allergy to Clarithromycin or Macrolides
•	History of bone marrow transplant
•	Chronic hemodialysis or Glomerular Filtration Rate < 20ml/min
•	Pregnant or nursing
•	Severe liver disease
registration_responses.q14.question: ONE ARM IS THERAPEUTIC AND THE OTHER PROPHYLACTIC
registration_responses.q15.question:
Outcome Measures
Go to   

Primary Outcome Measures  :
1.	COVID Ordinal Outcomes Scale at 14 days [ Time Frame: Assessed once on day 0, 3, 8 and 15 after enrollment (enrollment is day 0) ]
Per https://www.who.int/blueprint/priority-diseases/key-action/COVID-19_Treatment_Trial_Design_Master_Protocol_synopsis_Final_18022020.pdf, this scale reflects a range from uninfected to dead, where 0 is "no clinical or virological evidence of infection", 1 is "no limitation of activities", 2 is "limitation of activities", 3 is "hospitalized, no oxygen therapy", 4 is "oxygen by mask or nasal prongs", 5 is "non-invasive ventilation or high-flow oxygen", 6 is "intubation and mechanical ventilation", 7 is "ventilation + additional organ support - pressors, RRT (renal replacement therapy), ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation)", and 8 is "death".
 Primary Outcome Measures  :
1.	Hospitalization [ Time Frame: 14 days ]
All-cause hospitalization
1.	 Viral load [ Time Frame: 3 days ]
2.	Viral load by collected nasal swab and PCR [ Time Frame: 7 days ]

Secondary Outcome Measures  :
1.	Hospital-free days at 28 days (number of days patient not in hospital) [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 28 days after admission (day 28) ]
Calculated as a worst-rank ordinal (death is counted as -1 days).

2.	Ventilator-free days at 28 days (number of days patient not on a ventilator) [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 28 days after admission (day 28) ]
Calculated as a worst-rank ordinal (death is counted as -1 days).

3.	ICU-free days at 28 days (number of days patient not in an ICU) [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 28 days after admission (day 28) ]
Calculated as a worst-rank ordinal (death is counted as -1 days).

4.	Time to a 1-point decrease in the WHO ordinal recovery score [ Time Frame: Admission (day 1) to 14 days after admission (day 14) ]
